{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox mountain |name=Fanjingshan |photo=梵淨山紅雲金頂（新金頂）.jpg |photo_caption=The "Red Cloud Golden Peak" (New Golden Peak) of Fanjingshan |map=China |location=[[Tongren]], [[Guizhou]], [[China]] |elevation_m=2570 |translation=Mountain of the Pure Land of Brahma |language=[[Chinese language|Chinese]] |embedded={{designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = WHS | designation1_offname = Fanjingshan | designation1_date = [[List of World Heritage Sites by year of inscription#2018 (42nd session)|2018]] <small>(42nd [[World Heritage Committee|session]])</small> | designation1_type = Natural | designation1_criteria = (x) | Year = 2018 | area = 40,275 ha | buffer_zone = 37,239 ha | designation1_number = [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1559 1559] | designation1_free1name = State Party | designation1_free1value = {{flag|China}} | designation1_free2name = Region | designation1_free2value = [[List of World Heritage Sites in Eastern Asia|Eastern Asia]] }} }} The '''Fanjingshan''' ({{zh|c=梵净山|p=Fànjìngshān}}) or '''Mount Fanjing''', located in [[Tongren]], [[Guizhou]] province, is the highest peak of the [[Wuling Mountains]] in southwestern China, at an elevation of {{Convert|2,570|m||abbr=on}}. The '''Fanjingshan National Nature Reserve''' was established in 1978 and designated a [[UNESCO]] Biosphere Reserve in 1986. Fanjingshan is a sacred mountain in [[Chinese Buddhism]], considered to be the [[bodhimaṇḍa]] of the [[Maitreya]] Buddha. It became a UNESCO [[World Heritage Site]] in 2018.
== Name == The mountain's name "Fanjing" is an abbreviation of ''Fantian Jingtu'' (梵天净土), or "Brahma's Pure Land". ''Fantian'' is the Chinese name for the [[Four Heavenly Kings|Buddhist heavenly king]] [[Brahmā (Buddhism)|Brahmā]], and ''Jingtu'' is Chinese for "[[pure land]]", the focus of [[Pure Land Buddhism]].<ref name=":0" />
== Location and environment == Fanjingshan is located in [[Tongren]], Guizhou Province in southwest China. It is the highest peak of the [[Wuling Mountains]]. The elevation of its terrain ranges from {{convert|480|to(-)|2,570|m|sp=us}} above sea level.<ref name="MAB">{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?mode=all&code=CPR+04|title=Biosphere Reserve Information: Fanjingshan|work=UNESCO – MAB Biosphere Reserves Directory|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=3 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="WHC">{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1559|title=Fanjingshan|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=3 July 2018}}</ref>
The Fanjingshan National Nature Reserve was established in 1978 and designated a UNESCO [[Biosphere Reserve]] in 1986.<ref name="MAB" /> The reserve covers a total area of {{convert|567|km2|abbr=on}} and is a conservation area for primitive vegetation of the mid sub-tropic alpine region of western China.<ref name="MAB" /> The mountain was designated a [[World Heritage Site]] in July 2018.<ref name="WHC" />
Fanjingshan's relative isolation has ensured a high degree of biodiversity. Endemic species such as the rare [[Guizhou golden monkey]] ''(Rhinopithecus brelichi)'' and the Fanjingshan fir ''(Abies fanjingshanensis)'' occur only in a small region centering on Fanjingshan.<ref name="MAB" /><ref name="WHC" /> Several endangered species, including the [[Chinese giant salamander]], [[forest musk deer]], and [[Reeve's pheasant]] are also found in Fanjingshan. It is also home to the largest and most contiguous subtropical primeval beech forest.<ref name="WHC" />
== Buddhism == [[File:梵淨山風景.jpg|thumb|Fanjingshan]] [[File:Fanjingshan-new.jpg|thumb|The Mushroom Rock]]
Fanjingshan is considered a sacred mountain of [[Chinese Buddhism]],<ref name="MAB" /> ranking just behind the [[Four Sacred Mountains of Buddhism]]. It is considered the [[bodhimaṇḍa]] (or ''daochang'')--a spot in which one reached enlightenment--of the [[Maitreya]] Buddha.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.trsmzw.gov.cn/html/2014/zongjiao_1014/52.html|title=铜仁梵净山佛教文化综述|last=|first=|date=|website=Government of Tongren|language=Chinese|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 July 2018}}</ref> The influence of Buddhism reached Fanjingshan by the [[Tang dynasty]] at the latest, especially after Hou Hongren (侯弘仁) constructed the Zangke Road (牂牁道) in 639 AD, which facilitated transport in the mountainous region, and local gazettes record the construction of several temples in the area.<ref name=":0" /> More temples were built during the ensuing [[Song dynasty|Song]] and [[Yuan dynasty|Yuan]] dynasties.<ref name=":0" />
Buddhism greatly prospered during the [[Ming dynasty|Ming]] and [[Qing dynasty|Qing]] dynasties, when the cult of Tianguan Maitreya (天冠弥勒) became dominant in Fanjingshan. The [[Bozhou rebellion]] in the late 16th century caused great damages to Fanjingshan's temples. After suppressing the rebellion, the [[Wanli Emperor]] ordered the monk Miaoxuan (妙玄) to rebuild the Golden Peak of Fanjingshan and the Cheng'en Temple (承恩寺), and many other temples were constructed in the area, ushering in the golden era for Buddhism in Fanjingshan.<ref name=":0" /> Most temples during the Ming and Qing dynasties belonged to the [[Pure Land Buddhism|Pure Land]] and the [[Linji school|Linji]] sects of Buddhism.<ref name=":0" />
In the turmoil that toppled the Qing dynasty, many temples were destroyed by marauding armies and bandits, and few monks remained in the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] era.<ref name=":0" /> After further destructions during the [[Cultural Revolution]], Buddhism has enjoyed a renaissance since the 1980s. Many old temples have been rebuilt and new ones constructed, including the Cheng'en Temple, Huguo Chan Temple (护国禅寺), Great Golden Buddha Temple (大金佛寺), and Longquan Temple (龙泉寺).<ref name=":0" />
In 2010, the Fanjingshan Buddhist Cultural Park was opened, with a Golden Hall that houses a five-meter-tall statue of the [[Maitreya]] Buddha made with {{convert|250|kg}} of gold and thousands of gems. It is said to be the largest gold Maitreya statue in the world.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gzfjs.gov.cn/2013/1128/foji1061.html|title=梵净山佛教文化苑|last=|first=|date=28 November 2013|website=Government of Tongren|language=Chinese|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=7 July 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{short description|Study of the relationships between the symbolism and the ecology of the plants, fungi and animals associated with cultural events}} {{COI|date=July 2016}} '''Festive ecology''' explores the relationships between the [[symbol]]ism and the [[ecology]] of the [[plant]]s, [[fungi]] and [[animal]]s associated with cultural events such as [[festivals]], [[processions]], and special occasions. Examples of topics are given below.
==Christmas== The plants traditionally associated with [[Christmas]] – [[holly]], [[ivy]], [[mistletoe]], [[common yew]] - have had special roles in earlier religions and past cultures. Some early religions in [[Europe]] had midwinter festivals to celebrate the return of the sun from the shortest day. In the 4th and 5th centuries, 25 December was gradually adopted as the date for Christmas in Europe in order to superimpose on the existing mid-winter festivals. The [[winter solstice]] in the Northern Hemisphere, on what is now 17 December, was the start of the Roman festival of [[Saturnalia]]. This was a week of public feasting, dancing, singing and gambling. Houses were decorated with evergreens and bunches of holly were given as tokens of friendship. When this festival was absorbed into the Christian calendar, holly and the other evergreens were absorbed as well.
===Holly=== Holly is palatable to livestock despite its spines and was extensively used as a winter fodder for livestock in medieval times in England and Wales, particularly in [[Cumbria]], the [[Pennines]] and the [[Welsh borders]].<ref name=Spray>Spray, M (1981). Holly as a fodder in England. ''Agricultural History Review'' '''29''', 97-110.</ref> Hay and grains for wintering stock would often have run short in these upland areas. This would mean that the livestock would eventually have to be slaughtered, causing real problems to medieval economies in the following years. Thus, a supply of fresh browse would have been extremely valuable. Written records of payments and agreements involving the use of holly for livestock cover a wide period from the late 12th century to the mid-18th century, by which time the practice had been largely abandoned.<ref name=Spray/> An early reference to the practice occurs in “[[The Dream of Rhonabwy]]”, a Welsh story from the [[Mabinogion]], a remarkable collection of medieval literature.<ref>Jones, Gwyn & Jones, Thomas (1949). ''The Mabinogion''. Revised edition 1989. JM Dent & Sons, London.</ref> Written before the 14th century, The Dream of Rhonabwy refers to the mid-12th century in [[Powys]]. The floor of the old black house of Heilyn Goch is described as being covered in the urine and dung of cows together with branches of holly whose tips had been eaten by the cattle.
===Ivy=== Ivy was used in garlands by the [[ancient Greece|ancient Greeks]] and the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] for religious ceremonies and for celebrating at other, more secular, occasions. It was strongly associated with Bacchus ([[Dionysus]]), the Greco-Roman god of [[wine]]. Since Roman times, ivy has been associated with wine and wine-making. Branches of evergreen ivy tied to a pole was often used as the “sign of the bush” indicating a place where wine or alcohol was for sale. Hence, the proverb “Good wine needs no bush” meaning that it is not necessary to advertise well-made goods. Ivy is less commonly seen in houses in Britain at Christmas compared to holly and mistletoe and it may be that established religions opposed its use in Christmas wreaths because of its association with drunkenness.
===Mistletoe=== [[File:Cutting the mistletoe (4541052376).jpg|thumb|left|Cuttting the Mistletoe in [[Builth Wells]] (1909]]
Mistletoe is an evergreen plant well known for its association with [[oak]] trees and [[Druids]] first documented by [[Pliny the Elder]] who wrote about the ceremonies of the [[Celt]]ic Druids in [[Gaul]] in his ''[[Naturalis]] Historia''.<ref>Rackham, H (1952). ''Pliny: Natural History'', Book XVI, para xcv. Heinemann, London.</ref> These Druids held the oak in particular veneration, used oak leaves in their ceremonies, and regarded anything growing on oak trees as having been sent from heaven. On the rare occasions when mistletoe was found growing on an oak, it would be gathered with great ceremony. A priest in white clothing would cut the mistletoe with a golden sickle and allow it to fall onto a white cloak; two white bulls would then be sacrificed. According to Pliny, it was believed that mistletoe in a drink would make any barren animal fertile and that it was a remedy for all poisons. Special powers are attributed to mistletoe by a wide range of cultures, both within Europe and further afield.<ref>Frazer, J G (1922). ''The Golden Bough''. Macmillan, London.</ref> The use of mistletoe as an all-heal and a cure for barrenness is reputed to have a very ancient history.<ref>Graves, R (1955). ''The Greek Myths''. Penguin, Harmondsworth.</ref> The link between mistletoe and fertility persists to this day in Britain in the tradition of kissing underneath bunches of mistletoe at Christmas. In the early 19th century, it was traditional for each man who kissed under the mistletoe to remove one berry. Once all the berries are gone, so is the potency. {{clearleft}} ===Yew Trees=== Yew trees continually put out new stems which coalesce with the existing trunk resulting in trees of great age. The merging of old and decaying wood with vibrant young shoots has led to the yew being traditionally associated with [[reincarnation]] and [[immortality]].<ref>Cornish, V (1946). ''The Churchyard Yew and Immortality''. Frederick Muller, London.</ref>
==Dressing the Arbor Tree, Aston-on-Clun, Shropshire, England== [[File:Arbour tree, Aston on Clun (1293722).jpg|thumb|Arbour tree, [[Aston on Clun]], 1920's]] The custom of dressing the Arbor tree – a [[black poplar]] growing in [[Aston-on-Clun]] in south Shropshire – with flags on flagpoles every 29 May is almost unique in Britain,<ref>Box, John (2003). Dressing the Arbor tree. ''Folklore'' '''114''', 13-28.</ref> although "[[Appleton_Thorn#Bawming_the_Thorn|Bawming the Thorn]]" at [[Appleton Thorn]] in [[Cheshire]] is not dissimilar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.information-britain.co.uk/customdetail.php?id=19|title=British Folk Customs, Bawming the thorn, Cheshire|author=|date=|website=www.information-britain.co.uk|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> New flags are attached to wooden flagpoles on the Arbor tree which remain throughout the year.
The Arbor tree is a male black poplar tree growing beside a stream at a place where four roads meet. Written records of the Arbor tree only extend back to 1898, but the tradition of dressing the tree is reputed to date back to a local wedding in 1786. The custom has developed and acquired new meanings, particularly since the 1955 when a pageant was devised. The pageant and the celebrations associated with the tree dressing are evolving in response to those living in the local community as well as to the external recognition now accorded to this unique tradition.
The present black poplar grew from a rooted cutting taken from the old tree which was said to be at least 300 years old when it collapsed in 1995 and had been repeatedly pollarded. Black poplar is an extremely unusual tree to be associated with notable events or traditions, which are more likely to involve [[pedunculate oak]], [[sessile oak]], common yew or hawthorn (''[[Crataegus]]'').
The black poplar (''Populus nigra'' var. ''betulifolia'') is an uncommon native tree in Britain. Black poplars are associated with alluvial soils in river valleys and floodplains generally south of a line from the [[River Mersey]] to the estuary of the [[Humber]] with particular concentrations across the [[English Midlands|Midlands]] from the [[Welsh Marches]] to [[East Anglia]] and notably in the Vale of Aylesbury ([[Aylesbury Vale]]).<ref>Mabey, Richard (1996). ''Flora Britannica''. [[Sinclair-Stevenson]], London.</ref> A male clone ([[cloning]]) was much planted in the suburbs of [[Manchester]] in the late 18th century as it grew well in the polluted atmosphere and it became known as the ‘Manchester poplar’. Growing to a height of some 30 metres, the bark of the black poplar is distinctively ridged and furrowed and has characteristic large burrs or bosses. When mature, the tree forms a huge dome of massive spreading branches which arch outwards. This spreading habit is dramatically different from the elongated shape of the Lombardy poplar (''Populus nigra'' ‘Italica’) which, surprisingly, is a cultivated variety of the black poplar that was imported to [[Essex]] from [[Turin]] in 1758 and widely planted because of its unusual shape. The black poplar is also a different species from the more widespread black Italian poplar (''Populus'' x ''euramericana'' or ''Populus'' x ''canadensi''s) which is a hybrid between the black poplar and the North American eastern cottonwood (''[[Populus deltoides]]'').
Poplars are unusual in that there are separate male and female trees. Male black poplars are far more numerous than female trees in Britain and seedlings are, therefore, very rare.<ref>Milne-Redhead, Edgar (1990). The BSBI black poplar survey, 1973-88. ''Watsonia'' '''18''', 1-5.</ref> Regrowth occurs from the branches or trunk of fallen trees which root into the underlying soil. Growing in river valleys and floodplains, the trees can be uprooted by floods and grow again in a new location.
==Other== Accounts of other traditional customs on 29 May are usually linked to Royal Oak Day ([[Oak Apple Day]]) and include the surviving customary rights in [[Grovely Wood]] at [[Great Wishford]], [[Wiltshire]], and [[Castleton Garland Day|Garland King Day]] at [[Castleton, Derbyshire|Castleton]] (Derbyshire).

'''Gondhali''' is a community in [[Maharashtra]], India. Their occupation is to sing songs of the Goddesses of Maharashtra. Their songs are usually the mythological stories of their Gods. They use [[sambal (drum)|sambal]], a set of drums tied to their neck and rested on their thighs to bring rhythm to their songs.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DftkAAAAMAAJ&q=gondhali+community&dq=gondhali+community|title=The Oxford Companion to Indian Theatre|last=Lal|first=Ananda|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195644463|location=|pages=135|language=en}}</ref>
This singing and dancing in front of the God is called Gondhal and people who do Gondhal are called Gondhali.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6ZrjC24PuDQC&pg=PA93&lpg=PA93&dq=gondhal+ritual#v=onepage&q=gondhal%20ritual&f=false|title=History of Indian Theatre|last=Varadpande|first=Manohar Laxman|date=1987|publisher=Abhinav Publications|year=|isbn=9788170172789|location=|pages=93|language=en}}</ref>

__NOTOC__ In [[Greek mythology]], '''Graecus''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɡ|r|iː|k|ə|s}} ([[Ancient Greek language|Ancient Greek]]: {{lang|grc|Γραικός}}) was the son of [[Pandora II]] and [[Zeus]].<ref>Hesiod, ''[[Catalogue of Women]]'' fr. 5.</ref> His mother [[Pandora II]] (named after her grandmother [[Pandora]]) was the daughter of [[Deucalion]] and [[Pyrrha]] and sister of [[Hellen]] who together with his three sons [[Dorus]], [[Xuthus]] (with his sons [[Ion (mythology)|Ion]] and [[Achaeus, son of Xuthus|Achaeus]]) and [[Aeolus (son of Hellen)|Aeolus]], comprised the set of ancient tribes that formed the [[Greece|Greek]]/[[Ancient Greece|Hellenic]] nation.
==Later traditions== According to [[Stephanus of Byzantium]], Graecus was a son of [[Thessalus]]. According to [[Virgil]], [[Latinus]] is Graecus's brother. The [[Graecians]], a Hellenic tribe, took their name from Graecus, according to legend. They were one of the first Greek tribes to colonise [[Italy]]. The area that came to be known as [[Magna Graecia]] then took its name after them. The [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Latins]] used the term in reference to all [[Ancient Greeks|Hellenic]] people because the first [[Greeks|Hellenes]] they came into contact with were the Graecians.

'''Ian Henry Murray Marsh''' (born 8 December 1948) is an English musician and composer, best known as a member of the pop group [[Sailor (band)|Sailor]].<ref name="sailor site">{{cite web |title=Sailor website |url=http://www.sailor-music.com/henry.htm |accessdate=23 Jan 2014 }}</ref>
Marsh was born in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], Somerset. He was educated at [[Sherborne School]] and [[New College, Oxford|New College]], Oxford.<ref name="sailor site"/>
==Career== Marsh's first group was at school; [[Jeremy Irons]] was the drummer.<ref name=who/> After Oxford, Marsh joined a group with, among others, [[John G. Perry]], at first called Toast, which expanded to become Gringo.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gringo web-site |url=http://badcatrecords.com/BadCat/GRINGO.htm |accessdate=23 Jan 2014 }}</ref> He was invited in 1973 by [[Phil Pickett]] to join a group called Kajanus Pickett, after Pickett and [[Georg Kajanus]]. The group became [[Sailor (band)|Sailor]] with the inclusion of [[Grant Serpell]]. Sailor's original line-up split up in 1978,<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p20322/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Sailor |author=Thompson, Dave |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=April 11, 2010}}</ref> although Pickett and Marsh released more material as Sailor with Gavin and Virginia David in 1980, with an album of Pickett compositions called ''Dressed for Drowning''.
After Sailor disbanded, he worked with Kajanus on [[DATA (band)|DATA]] and "And The Mamluks", a short-lived electronic-music project. Marsh eventually teamed up with writer [[Barry Mason]] in 1986. They and David H. Bell, a Broadway director, wrote a musical called ''Malibu'', first performed in 1991. He wrote another musical, ''Casper—The Musical'', with Pickett in 1999. Marsh has written musical scores for theatre productions including ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', ''[[The Grapes of Wrath]]'' and ''[[The Dark at the Top of the Stairs]]''. He received the [[Joseph Jefferson Award]] for Best Original Music in Theater Production in 1998 for ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'',<ref name=who/> and in 1999 for ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Chicago Tribune |last=Eng |first=Monica |date=27 November 1998 }}</ref><ref name="imdb">{{cite web |title=IMDb |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1546902/bio?ref_=nm_ov_bio_sm#mini_bio |accessdate=23 Jan 2014 }}</ref> He also received a best composer nomination for ''[[As You Like It]]'' in 2002.<ref name="imdb"/> In 2004 he was nominated for two Jefferson Awards for ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'' and ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]''.<ref name="imdb"/>
His musical theatre work in the USA includes ''One Last Summer'', ''In Stitches'' and ''Female Problems'' for which he received a nomination for Best New Work. His musical theatre work in the UK includes ''The Mask'', ''Spider-Man'' and ''Casper''. Marsh has composed numerous scores for television. These include ''[[Eye of the Storm (TV series)|Eye of the Storm]]'' (ITV drama), ''Pirates'' (BBC drama), ''[[Blockbusters (UK game show)|Blockbusters]]'', ''[[Strike It Lucky|Strike It Rich]]'', ''Black Date'' (Channel 4), ''[[Win, Lose or Draw (UK game show)|Win Lose Or Draw]]'' (Granada Television), ''The Fastest Man On Earth'' (ITV and Discovery Channel) and ''[[House Invaders (TV series)|House Invaders]]'' (BBC). His library music has been used worldwide for film and television, including ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air]]'', ''Private Parts (the movie)'', ''[[Father Ted]]'', ''[[Home and Away]]'', ''[[Peak Practice]]'' and many others.<ref name="sailor site"/> He composed the music for the film ''SON of Nosferatu'' (2011).<ref name="imdb"/>
In 1989 Sailor reformed with Marsh.<ref name="AMG"/> He left in 1999 but returned in 2005. Marsh's sons, Oliver and Thomas, have also performed with the band in recent years.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sailor Bookings |url=http://www.sailorbookings.com/index.html |accessdate=23 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601171150/http://www.sailorbookings.com/index.html |archivedate=1 June 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Personal life== In April 1970 Marsh married Susan Norddahl; they had two sons and a daughter before their divorce.<ref name=who/> Marsh subsequently married Patricia "Dee Dee" Wilde, founder member of [[Pan's People]]. They jointly run WM Productions, a video production company.<ref>{{cite web |title=Retrosellers |url=http://www.retrosellers.com/features424.htm |accessdate=23 Jan 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202160946/http://www.retrosellers.com/features424.htm |archivedate=2014-02-02 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Carina Baverstock |url=http://carinabcouture.blogspot.co.uk/2011/10/show-time.html |accessdate=23 Jan 2014 }}</ref> As of 2002, they lived in [[Rood Ashton House|Rood Ashton]], Wiltshire.<ref name=who/> Marsh has been practising [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] since the early 1980s;<ref name=who>{{cite book|title=The International Who's Who in Popular Music 2002|date=2002|publisher=Europa Publications|page=336|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gZIjT8PgJMEC&pg=PA336&lpg=PA336&dq=%22The+International+Who%27s+Who+in+Popular+Music%22+marsh+henry&source=bl&ots=XAUTfGQb3Z&sig=ajZZSszCpMdPp5xBfozEi3sYvQw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Dq0RVML4G-ar7AaB14DIBA&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22The%20International%20Who%27s%20Who%20in%20Popular%20Music%22%20marsh%20henry&f=false|accessdate=11 September 2014}}</ref> Wilde is also a practitioner.<ref>{{cite news|title=Diggin' the Dancing Queens |first=Claire Marie |last=Miszewska |work=The Express |location=UK|date=December 8, 2001 |page=41}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{Hermeticism}} The '''Hermetic Brotherhood of Light''' was a Fraternity that descended from the [[Fratres Lucis]] in the late 18th century (in turn, derived from the German [[Order of the Golden and Rosy Cross]]), and was the seed from which [[Ordo Templi Orientis]] (O.T.O.) ('Order of the Temple of the East' or 'Order of Oriental Templars') was created.
[[Carl Kellner (mystic)|Carl Kellner]] and [[Paschal Beverly Randolph]] were members of the Hermetic Brotherhood of Light. In [[Theodor Reuss]]' 1917 O.T.O. Constitution, it states in Article 1, Section 1: :''Under the style and title: ANCIENT ORDER OF ORIENTAL TEMPLARS, an organization, formerly known as: "The Hermetic Brotherhood of Light", has been reorganized and reconstituted. This reconstituted association is an international organization, and is hereinafter referred to as the O.T.O.''
==Sources== *[[Allen H. Greenfield|Greenfield, Allen]]. ''The Story of the Hermetic Brotherhood of Light.'' Luxor Press *____. ''Hermetic Brotherhood Revisited.'' Luxor Press *Godwin, Joscelyn. (1990). "The Brotherhood of Light." ''Theosophical History'', Vol. III, No. 3

'''Hisbah''' ({{lang-ar|حسبة}} ''ḥisbah'') is an [[Islam]]ic doctrine which means "accountability".<ref name=sz>Sami Zubaida (2005), Law and Power in the Islamic World, {{ISBN|978-1850439349}}, pages 58-60</ref> Hisbah is the divinely-sanctioned duty of the ruler (government) to intervene and coercively "[[enjoining good and forbidding wrong]]" in order to keep everything in order according to [[sharia]] (Islamic law).<ref name=lv>Lorenzo Vidino (2013), [http://www.css.ethz.ch/publications/pdfs/Hisba_in_Europe.pdf Hisba in Europe?], European Foundation for Democracy, Switzerland</ref> The doctrine is based on an expression from the [[Quran]] ({{lang|ar|الأمر بالمَعْرُوف والنَهي عن المُنْكَر}}).<ref name=sz/><ref>[[Michael Cook (historian)|Michael Cook]]: ''Commanding right and forbidding wrong in Islamic thought.'' Cambridge University Press. Cambridge 2000. {{ISBN|0-521-66174-9}}</ref>{{page needed|date=April 2016}} Clear procedures are required to be followed in order to enact punishment under sharia,<ref>[http://www.lettertobaghdadi.com/ Open Letter to Al-Baghdadi] Accessed 16 February 2017.</ref> however [[Al-Jama'a al-Islamiyya]] (considered a terrorist organization) suggests that it is the sacred duty of all Muslims, not just rulers.<ref name=lv/>
==Description== The Hisbah has the following major aspects:<ref>Michael Cook (2003), ''Forbidding Wrong in Islam.'' Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-82913-5}}</ref> *An obligation of a [[Muslim]]. *An obligation of a state to ensure its citizens comply with ''hisbah'' such as [[sharia]]. *In a broader sense, ''hisbah'' also refers to the practice of supervision of commercial, guild, and other secular affairs. Traditionally, a [[muhtasib]] (al-Muhtasib) was appointed by the [[caliph]] to oversee the order in marketplaces, in businesses, in medical occupations, etc. The position of muhtasib may be approximately rendered as "[[inspector]]". See [[Hisbah (business accountability)]] for this aspect.
For example, in [[Saudi Arabia]], the state establishment responsible for ''hisbah'' is the [[Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)|Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice]], or Hai'a.<ref>Sherifa Zuhur (2012), Saudi Arabia, {{ISBN|978-1598845716}}, pages 431-432</ref>
In a minority of Islamic states, namely Saudi Arabia, Sudan, the Aceh province of Indonesia and Iran, there is an establishment of [[Islamic religious police]]. In some places, it is state-established; in others, it is independent of the state.
Hisbah doctrine has been invoked by Islamic prosecutors in cases of apostasy and acts of [[blasphemy]]. For example, in [[Egypt]], [[Nasr Abu Zayd]], a Muslim scholar "critical of old and modern Islamic thought" was prosecuted under the doctrine when his academic work was held to be evidence of [[Apostasy in Islam|apostasy]].<ref>M. Berger, Apostasy and Public Policy in Contemporary Egypt: An Evaluation of Recent Cases from Egypt's Highest Courts, Human Rights Quarterly, Volume 25, Number 3, August 2003, pages 720-740</ref><ref>Olsson, S. (2008), Apostasy in Egypt: Contemporary Cases of Ḥisbah. The Muslim World, 98(1): 95-115</ref>
==See also== *[[Hisbah bill]]

{{Infobox artist | name = Jeanne Tripier | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1869 | birth_place = [[Paris, France]] | death_date = 1944 | death_place = | field = {{plainlist| * [[Drawing]] * [[Embroidery]] }} | training = | movement = {{plainlist| * [[Art brut]] * [[Outsider art]] }} | works = | patrons = [[Jean Dubuffet]] | awards = | signature = }}
'''Jeanne Tripier''' (1869–1944) was a French [[Mediumship|medium]]<ref name="Dictionary of Women Artists">{{cite book|last1=Gaze|first1=Delia ed.|title=Dictionary of Women Artists: Artists, J-Z|date=1997|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0316589063|page=96}}</ref> who produced works of text, drawing and embroidery under [[Spiritualism|Spiritualist]] influence. She is considered part of the [[Outsider art|Art Brut]] canon.<ref name="Wertkin">{{cite book|last1=Wertkin|first1=Gerard C. ed.|title=Encyclopedia of American Folk Art|year=2004|publisher=Routledge.|isbn=0-415-92986-5|page=400}}</ref> ==Life==
Jeanne Tripier was born in 1869 in [[Paris]].<ref name="Maclagan">{{cite book|last1=Maclagan|first1=David|title=Outsider Art: From the Margins to the Marketplace|year=2009|publisher=Reaktion Books|isbn=978-1861895219|page=184}}</ref> Daughter of a wine merchant, she spent her childhood in the country with her grandmother.<ref name="ABCD">{{cite web|title=TRIPIER jeanne|url=http://abcd-artbrut.net/collection/tripier-jeanne/|publisher=Art Brut Collection ABCD|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref> As an adult she lived in the Montmartre district of Paris, working as a salesgirl at a department store. At 58 she developed a passion for [[Spiritualism|Spiritualist]] doctrines and divination. These activities became central to her existence, so much so that she eventually stopped going to work. In 1934 she was admitted to a psychiatric hospital in Paris.<ref name="Collection de l'art Brut Lausanne">{{cite web|title=Tripier, Jeanne|url=http://www.artbrut.ch/fr/21004/1030/tripier--jeanne|publisher=Collection de l'art Brut Lausanne|accessdate=8 March 2017}}</ref>
==Work== Jeanne Tripier began creating works which blended image and text when she was in her 50s. Tripier's work emerged during trance states<ref name="Spiritualist Art">{{cite work|title=Spiritualist Art|publisher=Collection de l'Art Brut Lausanne}}</ref> and utilized materials such as sugar and hair dye.<ref name="Frieze">{{cite web|last1=Zion|first1=Amy|title=Art Brut in America & Unorthodox|url=https://frieze.com/article/art-brut-america-unorthodox|publisher=Frieze|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref> She also produced figurative embroidery pieces. She ascribed responsibility for her output of texts, drawings, and embroideries to spiritual entities.<ref name="Line Let Loose">{{cite book|last1=Maclagan|first1=David|title=Line Let Loose: Scribbling, Doodling and Automatic Drawing|year=2014|publisher=Reaktion Books|isbn=1780230826|page=116}}</ref>
==Collections and exhibits==
Jeanne Tripier's work is primarily held in the [[Collection de l'Art Brut]] museum in [[Lausanne, Switzerland]].<ref name="Maclagan" /> Her works have been lent to other institutions for exhibitions, including the 2015 exhibit ''Art Brut in America: The Incursion of Jean Dubuffet'' at the [[American Folk Art Museum]].<ref name="folkartmuseum">{{cite web|title=Art Brut in America: The Incursion of Jean Dubuffet|url=http://folkartmuseum.org/exhibitions/art-brut-in-america-the-spirit-of-jean-dubuffet/|publisher=American Folk Art Museum|accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref>
==Recognition== [[Jean Dubuffet]] acquired Tripier's work for his Collection de l'Art Brut.<ref name="Collection de l'art Brut Lausanne" />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== [http://abcd-artbrut.net/collection/tripier-jeanne/ TRIPIER jeanne]

{{Infobox person | name = Larry Lea | residence = [[Rockwall, Texas|Rockwall]], Texas | other_names = | image = | image_size = 156px | caption = | birth_name = '''Harold Lawrence Lea''' | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1951|1|30|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | known = | occupation = [[minister of religion|preacher]] | title = | salary = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relations = | website = http://larrylea.webs.com | footnotes = | employer = | height = | weight = }}
'''Harold Lawrence "Larry" Lea''' (born January 30, 1951) is a pastor and [[televangelist]] in [[Rockwall, Texas|Rockwall]], Texas.
==Early years== He attended and graduated from [[Dallas Baptist University]] where he met his first wife, Melva. He completed his graduate work at [[Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary]] in Fort Worth.<ref name="evangelicalism333">Randall Herbert Balmer, ''Encyclopedia of Evangelicalism'', p. 333</ref> Larry and Melva married in 1972, and together they have 3 children.<ref name="wifeinterview"/> He became the youth pastor of '''Beverly Hills Baptist Church''' in Dallas, where the youth department shot up from 40 to 1,000. While pastoring [[Church on the Rock]] in Rockwall, Texas, He also served as Dean of Theological and Spiritual Affairs at [[Oral Roberts University]].<ref name="evangelicalism333"/>
==Church on the Rock== Following a stint as an itinerant preacher in the late 1970s, Lea was invited to pastor Church on the Rock in 1980 with 12 people in [[Rockwall, Texas|Rockwall]], Texas, a suburb of Dallas. Within 5 years, the congregation had increased to over 5,000. In 1986, Lea began to travel again, holding what he called "Prayer Clinics" and later, "Prayer Rallies" or "Prayer Breakthroughs". Also, that year marked the beginning of Lea's television program, called ''Change Your Life''. Also, that year, Lea released his first book, the best-seller<ref>http://www.powells.com/biblio?show=TRADE%20PAPER:USED:9780884192107:6.50</ref> ''Could You Not Tarry One Hour?'', which was his teaching on [[The Lord's Prayer]]. He also began a partnership group where his partners were referred to as "[[prayer warrior|Prayer Warriors]]".
In June 1990, Lea stepped aside as pastor to oversee Church on the Rock, which was a group of churches that was called a "virtual denomination" according to ''[[Christianity Today]]''.<ref>Kim lawton, "Broadcasters face ethics questions - again," ''Christianity Today'', January 13, 1992</ref> (The successor of this organization, still named COTRI, is led by former Church on the Rock assistant pastor Dr. Lawrence Kennedy. Under Lea COTRI had 45 churches nationwide; now the number includes over 350 in the U.S.{{Citation needed|reason=Cotri.org does not appear to specify this number.|date=August 2010}} and thousands worldwide.<ref>http://cotri.org/content.asp?menuid=About%20Us&Contentid=Overview</ref>)
==Controversies== Lea found himself in some controversy later that year, when Lea and several ministers met at the [[Bill Graham Civic Auditorium|Civic Auditorium]] in [[San Francisco]]. Lea's ministry was heavily criticized by an assortment of gay-rights activists, pro-choice activists, and [[Wiccans]] led by Eric Pryor (who later converted to Christianity<ref>http://www.charismamag.com/index.php/news/22317-wiccan-turned-bible-teacher-eric-pryor-dies?</ref>). On Halloween (the first night of the crusade), there was a massive protest<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toobeautiful.org/chron_901101.html |title=San Francisco Chronicle, 1 November 1990: 6,500 Christians Attend S.F. 'Exorcism' |publisher=Toobeautiful.org |date=1990-11-01 |accessdate=2010-08-17}}</ref> leading to many who came to the Civic Auditorium having to come through a very hostile crowd outside and concerns about potential violence forced Lea to drop plans for 5,000 attendees to conduct a [[Prayer walk|prayer march]] through the city's streets.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stein|first1=Mark A.|title=He Came, Saw but Couldn't Conquer : San Francisco: An evangelist and his 'prayer warriors' are met by 1,500 demonstrators on Halloween. He had hoped to 'exorcise sin' in the city.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-02/news/mn-3720_1_san-francisco|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=27 December 2017|date=November 2, 1990}}</ref>
A year later, ABC's ''[[Primetime (U.S. TV program)|PrimeTime Live]]'' aired an exposé involving Lea and fellow Dallas-area televangelists [[W.V. Grant]] and [[Robert Tilton]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://docs.newsbank.com/g/GooglePM/DM/lib00377,0ED56291649D24AC.html | title=Judgment Day on `Prime Time Live' |publisher=[[Dallas Morning News]] | date=November 21, 1991 | first= Ed| last= Bark| accessdate = 2007-01-18}}</ref> The incident involving Lea came as a result of his fundraising appeals, questions as to how much money was going to mentioned projects (specifically a program involving helping start churches in [[Poland]]),<ref name="ReferenceA">Susan Lockamy, "Ethics Panel Exonerates Lea," ''Charisma'', July 1992</ref> and accusations that Lea implied a fire at one of his homes left his family almost destitute even though they still had a five-million-dollar home in the Dallas area.
==Aftermath== Lea's organization had grown so quickly, he made the decision to allow the [[National Religious Broadcasters]] financial integrity arm, EFICOM (Ethics and Financial Integrity Commission), to audit his ministry to look into the charges.<ref name="wifeinterview">{{cite news | url=http://www.charismamag.com/index.php/features2/346-special-interview/5257-a-journey-toward-healing?format=pdf | title=Judgment A Journey Toward Healing |publisher=[[Charisma magazine]] | year=2002| first= | last= | accessdate = 2007-01-18}}</ref> While EFICOM would determine he had been delinquent in sending his financial information, the group determined that Lea had not misused the funds for the Poland project. The EFICOM committee also accused [[ABC News]] of misleading Lea about the interview's purpose and ignoring "significant facts"; such as signed affidavits from Polish church officials that would have confirmed Lea's claims.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> By May 1992 (after ending his ''Change Your Life'' broadcasts the previous December after the expose), Lea would make a return to the airwaves with a show titled ''America, Let's Pray''.
His credibility and prominence in the charismatic community evaporated (though not as quickly as Tilton's), as he traveled with [[Morris Cerullo]] at the latter's crusades in the mid-1990s. Lea also claimed that he suffered a relapse of bipolar disorder.<ref name="wifeinterview"/> In 1994, he took a position as a pastor in [[San Diego]]. This lasted until 1997.
After 27 years of marriage, Larry filed for divorce in April 1999.<ref name="wifeinterview"/> During the divorce, his wife attended [[Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary]].<ref name="wifeinterview"/> Lea's son John started the '''Life Church''' in [[Rockwall, Texas|Rockwall]], Texas in the same Dallas suburb where Larry and his ex-wife began Church on the Rock in 1980.<ref name="wifeinterview"/> Lea has since remarried and has returned to the Rockwall area.<ref name="wifeinterview"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.larryleaministries.net/larryleanakedtruth.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412034906/http://www.larryleaministries.net/larryleanakedtruth.html |archivedate=2010-04-12 |df= }}</ref>
The Church on the Rock main campus was later sold to '''Lake Pointe Baptist Church''', a [[Southern Baptist]] [[megachurch]] in the Rockwall area which relocated to the site and renamed itself '''Lake Pointe Church'''; while the church itself moved to the nearby [[Rowlett, Texas|Rowlett]] area and was renamed Church in the City in January 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://citcchurch.org/index.php/welcome-page/about-citc/our-pastors |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826164631/http://citcchurch.org/index.php/welcome-page/about-citc/our-pastors |archivedate=2013-08-26 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://larrylea.webs.com// Larry Lea Ministries Homepage]

{{Infobox organization | name = Limmud | logo = Limmud_logo.png | type = Jewish educational [[Charitable organization|charity]]<ref name="Charity">Limmud is registered with the [[Charity Commission]] as charity no. 1083414. According to the Charity Commission, Limmud operates throughout England and Wales and also in Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, China, Croatia, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Hungary, India, Israel, Italy, Lithuania, Macedonia, Netherlands, New Zealand, Peru, Poland, Romania, Russia, Scotland, Serbia, South Africa, Sweden, Turkey, Ukraine and the United States of America. {{cite web | url=http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/find-charities/ | title=Limmud | publisher=[[Charity Commission]] | work=Find charities |date= 2 January 2014 |accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref> | founded_date = 1980 | founders = [[Clive Lawton]], [[Alastair Falk]], Michael May, Jonathan Benjamin | location = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] <!-- this parameter modifies "Headquarters" --> | origins = | key_people = {{unbulleted list|David Hoffman (Chair)}}<ref name="Hoffman">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/150433/lawyer-david-hoffman-appointed-new-chair-limmud | title=Lawyer David Hoffman appointed new chair of Limmud | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=30 November 2015 | accessdate=1 January 2016 | author=Rocker, Simon}}</ref> | area_served = | product = | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Wherever you find yourself, Limmud will take you one step further on your Jewish journey | homepage = {{url|https://www.limmud.org}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''Limmud''' is a [[British Jews|British-Jewish]] educational charity<ref name="Charity"/> which, in the UK, produces a large annual winter festival and several other regional events throughout the year on the theme of Jewish learning. Limmud is not affiliated to any strand of Judaism and markets itself as open to "anyone interested in Jewish learning".
Limmud (from the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word meaning "to learn")<ref name="Jeffay">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/dec/16/limmud | title='It's more academic than academia' | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=16 December 2008 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=Jeffay, Nathan}}</ref> was originally a conference for "educators",<ref name="Jeffay"/> basing itself on [[CAJE]], the Conference on Alternatives in Jewish Education of North America,<ref name="Falk interview">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/122247/the-man-leading-front-class | title=The man leading from the front of the class | work=''Interview with Alastair Falk in'' [[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=5 September 2014 | accessdate=5 September 2014 | author=Oliver, Charlotte}}</ref> formed in 1976. From CAJE, it took a volunteer ethos, not paying presenters, and not using people's titles. During the 1990s there was the significant change as Limmud reinvented itself as a community gathering, giving rise to a significant increase in the number of attendees and leading it to be described as "British Jewry's greatest export".<ref name="Export">{{cite news | url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/all-jewish-all-the-time-1.335748 | title=All Jewish, all the time | work=[[Haaretz]] | date=7 January 2011 | accessdate=14 January 2014 | author=Harman, Danna}}</ref> The Limmud model has now spread to many other countries.<ref name="Charity"/>
A distinctive feature of Limmud is that the events are organised by volunteers,<ref name=" Kustanowitz ">{{cite news | url=http://www.haaretz.com/misc/iphone-article/.premium-1.557408 | title=Seven ways to disrupt a Jewish conference | work=[[Haaretz]] | date=11 November 2013 | accessdate=14 January 2014 | author=Kustanowitz, Esther D}}</ref><ref name="Tulane">{{cite web|url=https://tulane.edu/news/newwave/030810_limmud_fest.cfm |title=‘Volunticipants’ Needed for Jewish Fest |publisher=[[Tulane University]] |work=New Wave |date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116085307/https://tulane.edu/news/newwave/030810_limmud_fest.cfm |archivedate=16 January 2014 |df= }}</ref> who also take part as equals in what is now called the Limmud Festival.<ref name="Export"/><ref name="Eisner"/> Limmud's largest group of volunteers are in their 20s and 30s.<ref name="Eisner">{{cite news | url=http://forward.com/articles/190369/what-limmud-can-teach-us/ | title=What Limmud Can Teach Us | work=[[The Forward]] | date=7 January 2014 | accessdate=14 January 2014 | author=Eisner, Jane | location=[[New York City|New York]]}}</ref> Around half of the UK "Forty under 40" (a community-wide initiative to identify the future leaders of British Jewry, published by ''[[The Jewish News (newspaper)|The Jewish News]]'') have volunteered for Limmud and a former Chair of Limmud, Elliott Goldstein, topped the list.<ref name="Elliott">{{cite news | url=http://archive.totallyjewish.com/news/elliott-is-number-one/ | title=Elliott is number one | work=[[The Jewish News (newspaper)|The Jewish News]] | date=17 June 2010 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=Marin, James | location=London}}</ref>
==Organisation==
Limmud is a company and a charity. It is run by a board of directors and trustees, all of whom are volunteers. Initially, there was no difference between Limmud the organisation and Limmud Conference, the annual event, so the chairs of the Conference/Festival team were the chairs of the organisation. In 1990, a chair for the organisation who was separate from the Conference chairs was appointed for the first time. In 2006, [[Limmud International]] was created, as a separate unit within Limmud to manage relationships with other Limmud groups around the world. Limmud International was absorbed back into Limmud at the end of 2016.

2017 - 2018 Shep Rosenman<ref>{{Cite book|title=Limmud Conference / Festival handbooks|last=|first=|publisher=|year=2002–2018|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
'''Chair of Limmud Israel'''
2018 Danielle Nagler<ref name="Nagler">{{cite news | url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/spotlight/times-of-israel-presents-limmud-israel-tel-aviv-after-dark-on-oct-22/ | title=Times of Israel Presents: Limmud Israel — Tel Aviv After Dark, on Oct. 22 | work=[[The Times of Israel]] | date=15 October 2018 | accessdate=30 November 2018 | author=TOI Staff}}</ref>
Limmud's first professional appointment in 1998 was of [[Clive Lawton]] as part-time Executive Director; he gradually became backed by a full-time administrator. In 2006 Limmud recruited its first full-time Executive Director, [[Raymond Simonson]], former Director of UJIA Makor: The Centre for Informal Jewish Education.<ref name="Simonson">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/70784/limmud-leader-simonson-heads-jcc | title=Limmud leader Simonson heads for the JCC | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=2 August 2012 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=Lipman, Jennifer}}</ref> When Simonson became Chief Executive of London's Jewish Community Centre,<ref name="Simonson" /> now [[JW3]], in 2012, he was succeeded by Shelley Marsh.<ref name="Marsh">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/community/community-life/84699/limmud-picks-shelley-marsh-top-job | title=Limmud picks Shelley Marsh for top job | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=4 October 2012 | accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> She stepped down from the role in 2015.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/132571/limmud-director-steps-down | title=Limmud director steps down | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=25 March 2015 | accessdate=27 March 2015 | author=Doherty, Rosa}}</ref> Mike Schindler was the Limmud Director of Operations and the senior professional in the organisation between March and August 2015,<ref name="Structure">{{cite web|url=https://limmud.org/volunteers/structure/ |title=Limmud the organisation – who's who |publisher=Limmud |accessdate=2 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203174601/http://limmud.org/volunteers/structure/ |archivedate= 3 February 2016 |df= }}</ref> and then Dani Serlin was Acting Executive Director until February 2016. In February 2016, Limmud appointed the current Chief Executive, Eli Ovits, as senior professional.<ref>http://www.jta.org/2016/02/01/news-opinion/world/global-limmud-names-jerusalem-us-eli-ovits-as-executive-director</ref>
==Limmud events in the UK==
===Limmud Festival=== '''Limmud Festival''' (until 2017 known as '''Limmud Conference'''), takes place every year in the last week of December<ref name=" Kahn-Harris">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2010/dec/29/limmud-conference-jewish | title=Limmud: a great Jewish alternative to Christmas | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=29 December 2010 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=[[Keith Kahn-Harris|Kahn-Harris, Keith]]}}</ref> and is the organisation's [[flagship]] event. It was inspired by the [[CAJE]] conference in the United States [http://www.caje.org/] and now attracts more than 2,000 participants annually;<ref name="Jeffay"/><ref name=" Kahn-Harris"/> in 2015 the numbers rose to 2,750.<ref name="2015 pictures">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/galleries/news-galleries/limmud-2015-pictures | title=Limmud 2015 in pictures | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=31 December 2015 | accessdate=2 January 2016}}</ref> A typical day at Limmud Festival includes around 200 sessions spanning religious, cultural and political aspects of Jewish life. After the first conferences at [[Carmel College (Oxfordshire)]],<ref name="Growth"/> Limmud Conference has been held at [[University of Portsmouth|Portsmouth Polytechnic]] (1984),<ref name="Growth">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/114276/how-limmud-has-grown | title=How Limmud has grown | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=23 December 2013 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=Easterman, Daniel}}</ref> [[Oxford Brookes University]] (1986–1994),<ref name="Growth"/> Worcester (1995–96), Manchester (1997), the [[University of Nottingham]] (1998–2006) and [[Warwick University]] (2007–14).<ref name="Growth"/> Since 2015 this annual event has been held at the hotels surrounding Pendigo Lake, near [[Birmingham]].<ref name="Conference 2015">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/151538/limmuds-new-venue-should-make-year-best-conference-yet-say-organisers | title=Limmud's new venue should make this year the best conference yet, say organisers | work=[[the Jewish Chronicle]]| author=Rocker, Simon | date= 21 December 2015|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="Jackman ">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/127523/limmud-2014-organisers-promise-bigger-event-next-year | title=Limmud 2014: Organisers promise bigger event next year | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=31 December 2014 | accessdate=31 December 2014 |author1=Dysch, Marcus |author2=Firsht, Naomi |author3=Jackman, Josh }}</ref>
===Limmud summer events=== Limmud held a summer event in the last week of August which was called Limmud Fest from 2004 to 2012 and Limmud in the Woods from 2013 to 2016.<ref name="Sheinman">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/110132/limmud-goes-camping-woods | title=Limmud goes camping in the Woods | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=11 August 2013 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=Sheinman, Anna}}</ref> It involved camping as well as staying indoors,<ref name="Sheinman"/> had a less intense programme centred on [[Shabbat]] and is more cultural and outdoors-focused than its winter sibling. Limmud Fest had a peak attendance of 650 people; Limmud in the Woods was attended by around 200–250 young adults and young families.<ref name="Sheinman"/>
===Day and weekend Limmud events=== The first Day Limmud was in Sheffield in the early 1980s, followed by Leeds in the mid-1990s. Day and weekend Limmuds are now held at a number of venues in the UK, including Birmingham,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://limmud.org/day/birmingham-wm/ |title=Limmud Birmingham WM 2016 |publisher=Limmud ===Other Limmud events in UK=== Other events run by Limmud in the UK. either on their own or in partnership with others. have included music events and the [[Florence Melton]] Adult Mini-School, organised in partnership with the [[London Jewish Cultural Centre]].
==Limmuds around the world== {{main|Limmud International}} The Limmud model has now spread to many other countries.<ref name="Charity"/> More than ninety communities in 42 countries on six continents have hosted Limmud events including, in 2013 for the first time, Hong Kong,<ref name="HK">{{cite web | url=http://ejewishphilanthropy.com/hong-kong-is-finally-limmud-trending/ | title=Hong Kong is Finally Limmud Trending | publisher=eJewish Philanthropy | date=13 March 2013 | accessdate=17 February 2014 | author=Lyons, Erica}}</ref> Peru,<ref name="Peru">{{cite news | url= http://www.jta.org/2013/10/15/news-opinion/world/limmud-debut-in-peru-draws-600#ixzz3FY3MkWiq | title=Limmud debut in Peru draws more than 600 | work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency | date=15 October 2013 | accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> India<ref name="Mumbai">{{cite news | url=http://ejewishphilanthropy.com/first-limmud-mumbai-event-draws-jews-from-across-the-subcontinent/ | title= First Limmud Mumbai Event Draws Jews from Across the Subcontinent | work= Jewish Philanthropy | date=5 November 2013 | accessdate=8 October 2014 | author=EJP}}</ref> and Montenegro.

==Relationships with Orthodoxy in Britain== The former London [[United Synagogue]] [[Beth Din]]'s Head [[Dayan (rabbinic judge)]], [[Chanoch Ehrentreu]], advised Orthodox rabbis not to attend Limmud Conference.<ref name="Lebens">{{cite news | url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/the-jewish-thinker/.premium-1.553846 | title=Why Orthodox rabbis shouldn’t boycott Limmud | work=[[Haaretz]] | date=22 October 2013 | accessdate=14 January 2014 | author=Lebens, Samuel}}</ref> However, in the UK many United Synagogue pulpit rabbis have attended Limmud. In December 2010 Rabbi [[Yitzchak Schochet]] of Mill Hill United Synagogue, who had been seen as a notable absentee and critic of Limmud, attended, took part in and taught at Limmud's 30th annual Conference. Following this he wrote on the synagogue's website: "''upon return all I could ask myself was, 'where was I until now?'''" <ref name="Schochet">{{cite web | url=http://www.shul.co.uk/readArticle.php?article=301 | title=When Lightning Didn’t Strike | publisher=Mill Hill, United Synagogue | work=Rabbi's Blog | date=3 January 2011 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=[[Yitzchak Schochet|Schochet, Yitzchak]]}}</ref>
[[Jonathan Sacks]] did not attend Limmud whilst being Chief Rabbi but attended when he was the head of [[Jews College]]. Sacks, when looking back on his rabbinate, considers Limmud to be one of the great successes of his time.<ref name="Big Think">{{cite web | url=http://bigthink.com/videos/big-think-interview-with-lord-rabbi-jonathan-sacks | title=Big Think Interview With Lord Rabbi Jonathan Sacks | publisher=Big Think | date=12 July 2010 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=Liebman, Jessica}}</ref>
Controversy erupted again in 2013 when newly elected Chief Rabbi [[Ephraim Mirvis]] announced his decision to attend.<ref name="Lebens"/> Subsequently, a public notice signed by seven leading Orthodox rabbis including Dayan [[Chanoch Ehrentreu]] and Rabbi [[Avrohom Gurwicz]] and published in the ''[[Jewish Tribune (UK)|Jewish Tribune]]'', attacked pluralism and urged "God-fearing Jews" not to participate in Limmud.<ref name="Lebens"/> This sparked condemnation by non-[[Charedi]] communal leaders, with [[Jewish Leadership Council]] chairman [[Mick Davis]], [[Board of Deputies]] president [[Vivian Wineman]] and United Synagogue president Stephen Pack writing to ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'' saying that the statement showed "a shocking failure of leadership".<ref name="Backlash">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/112475/limmud-backlash-over-visit-chief | title=Limmud backlash over visit by Chief | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=17 October 2013 | accessdate=7 January 2014 | author=Rocker, Simon}}</ref> ''The Jewish Chronicle'' itself described the statement as "crass, ill-judged and ultimately self-defeating".<ref name="Silence">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/comment-and-debate/leader/112494/chief-rabbi-mirviss-dignified-silence | title=Chief Rabbi Mirvis's dignified silence | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=17 October 2013 | accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref> Mirvis's attendance at the 2013 Limmud Conference was well received by fellow participants.<ref name="Mirvis">{{cite web | url=http://www.jewishtelegraph.com/limmud_2.html | title=Mirvis: Great to be Jewish at Limmud | work=[[Jewish Telegraph]] | year=2013 | accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> At least nine other United Synagogue rabbis also attended the event.<ref name="US rabbis">{{cite news | url=http://www.thejc.com/node/114428 | title=We’ll be there again next year, say US rabbis | work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] | date=2 January 2014 | accessdate=14 January 2014 | author=Rocker, Simon}}</ref>

This is a list of [[bishopric of Troyes|bishops of Troyes]].<ref>For the bishops previous to 1716 go to German Wikipedia – Languages: Deutsch</ref>
* 1716–1742 : [[Jacques-Bénigne Bossuet]] * 1742–1758 : [[M. Poncet de la Rivière]] * 1758–1761 : [[Jean-Baptiste-Marie Champion de Cicé]] * 1761–1790 : [[Louis-Mathias, Count de Barral|Louis-Claude-Mathias-Joseph Conte de Barral]] (later [[archbishop of Tours]])
In 1790 the [[ancien régime]] and the diocese were abolished by the [[French Revolution|French revolutionaries]]. The diocese was restored in 1791 and was given [[Civil Constitution of the Clergy|constitutional bishops]] by the regime.
* 1791–1793 : [[Augustin Sibille]] (constitutional bishop) * 1802–1802 : [[Marc-Antoine de Noé]] * 1802–1808 : [[Louis-Apolinaire de la Tour du Pin-Montauban]] * 1809–1825 : [[Etienne-Marie de Boulogne]] * 1825–1843 : [[Jacques-Louis-David de Seguin des Hons]] * 1843–1848 : [[Jean-Marie-Mathias Debelay]] (later [[Avignon|archbishop of Avignon]]) * 1848–1860 : [[Pierre-Louis Cœur]] * 1860–1875 : [[Emmanuel-Jules Ravinet]] * 1875–1898 : [[Pierre-Louis-Marie Cortet]] * 1898–1907 : [[Gustave-Adolphe de Pélacot]] (later [[Chambéry|archbishop of Chambéry]]) * 1907–1927 : [[Laurent-Marie-Etienne Monnier]] * 1927–1932 : [[Maurice Feltin]] (later [[bishop of Sens]], [[archbishop of Bordeaux]], [[archbishop of Paris]], also cardinal) * 1933–1938 : [[Joseph-Jean Heintz]] (later [[bishop of Metz]]) * 1938–1943 : [[Joseph-Charles Lefèbvre]] (later [[archbishop of Bourges]], also cardinal) * 1943–1967 : [[Julien Le Couëdic]] * 1967–1992 : [[André Pierre Louis Marie Fauchet]] * 1992–1998 : [[Gérard-Antoine Daucourt]] (later [[bishop of Orléans]]) * 1999 onwards : [[Marc-Camille-Michel Stenger]]

{{about|the preacher|the military officer|Mohammed Buba Marwa}}
'''Mohammed Marwa''' (died 1980), best known by his nickname '''Maitatsine''' (and less commonly, as ''AllahTatsine''), was a controversial preacher in [[Nigeria]]. ''Maitatsine'' is a [[Hausa language|Hausa]] word meaning "the one who damns" and refers to his curse-laden public speeches against the Nigerian state.<ref name=adesoji>{{cite journal | title = Between Maitatsine and Boko Haram: Islamic Fundamentalism and the Response of the Nigerian State | journal = Africa Today | date = Summer 2011 | first = Abimbola | last = Adesoji | volume = 57 | issue = 4 | pages = 98–119, 136| id = | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/883393210?accountid=10475 | accessdate = 2011-11-13}}</ref>
== Background == He was originally from [[Maroua|Marwa]] in northern [[Cameroon]].<ref name=Lubeck>{{cite journal|title=Islamic Protest under Semi-Industrial Capitalism: 'Yan Tatsine Explained|author=Paul M. Lubeck|journal=Africa: Journal of the International African Institute |volume=55 |issue=4 |year=1985 |pages=369–389 |jstor=1160172}}</ref> After his education he moved to [[Kano, Nigeria]] in about 1945, where he became known for his controversial preachings on the [[Qur'an]]. Although a Koranic scholar, he seemingly rejected the [[hadith]] and the [[sunnah]] and regarded the reading of any other book but the Koran as [[paganism]]. Maitatsine spoke against the use of radios, watches, bicycles, cars and the possession of more money than necessary.<ref name='kastfelt1989'>{{cite journal | title = Rumours of Maitatsine: A Note on Political Culture in Northern Nigeria | journal = African Affairs | year = 1989 | first = Niels | last = Kastfelt | volume = 88 | issue = 350 | pages = 83–90 | url = http://afraf.oxfordjournals.org/content/88/350/83.extract | accessdate = 2011-09-04}}</ref><ref name='pham'/>
The British [[Colonial Nigeria|colonial authorities]] sent him into [[exile]], but he returned to Kano shortly after [[Nigerian Independence|independence]]. By 1972 he had a notable and increasingly militant following known as ''[[Yan Tatsine]]''.<ref name='pham'>{{cite web|url=http://worlddefensereview.com/pham101906.shtml |title=In Nigeria False Prophets Are Real Problems |accessdate=2011-11-21 |last=Pham |first=J. Peter |date=2006-10-19 |work=worlddefensereview.com |publisher=World Defense Review |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130209115602/http://worlddefensereview.com/pham101906.shtml |archivedate=2013-02-09 |df= }}</ref> In 1975 he was again arrested by Nigerian police for slander and public abuse of political authorities<ref name=Lubeck/> But in that period he began to receive acceptance from religious authorities, especially after making [[hajj]], the Muslim pilgrimage to [[Mecca]].<ref name=Lubeck/> As his following increased in the 1970s, so did the number of confrontations between his adherents and the police. His preaching attracted largely a following of youths, unemployed migrants, and those who felt that mainstream Muslim teachers were not doing enough for their communities.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} By December 1980, continued Yan Tatsine attacks on other religious figures and police forced the Nigerian army to become involved. Subsequent armed clashes led to the deaths of around 5,000 people, including Maitatsine himself.<ref name='pham'/> Maitatsine died shortly after sustaining injuries in the clashes either from his wounds or from a heart attack.<ref name='hiskett'>{{cite journal | title = The Maitatsine Riots in Kano, 1980: An Assessment | journal = Journal of Religion in Africa | date = October 1987 | first = Mervyn | last = Hiskett | volume = 17 | issue = 3 | pages = 209–23 | jstor = 1580875 | doi=10.1163/157006687x00145}}</ref>
According to a 2010 article published by the [[Sunday Trust]] magazine the military cremated Maitatsine's remains, which now rest in a bottle kept at a police laboratory in Kano.<ref name="sundayTrust20101226">{{cite web | url=http://sundaytrust.com.ng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5631:maitatsine-30-years-after-kanos-most-deadly-violence&catid=44:feature&Itemid=135 | title=Maitatsine: 30 Years After Kano’s Most Deadly Violence | publisher=Daily Trust | work=Sunday Trust | date=2010-12-26 | accessdate=May 25, 2012 | author=Adamu, Lawan Danjuma}}</ref>
== Legacy == Despite Mohammed Marwa's death, Yan Tatsine riots continued into the early 1980s. In October 1982 riots erupted in [[Bulumkuttu]], near [[Maidaguri]],<ref name=Omotosho/> and in [[Kaduna]],<ref name=Omotosho/> to where many Yan Tatsine adherents had moved after 1980. Over 3,000 people died. Some survivors of these altercations moved to [[Yola, Nigeria|Yola]], and in early 1984 more violent uprisings occurred in that city.<ref name=Omotosho/> In this round of rioting, [[Musa Makaniki]], a close disciple of Maitatsine, emerged as a leader and Marwa's successor.<ref name='pham'/><ref name='hiskett'/> Ultimately more than 1,000 people died in Yola and roughly half of the city's 60,000 inhabitants were left homeless. Makaniki fled to his hometown of [[Gombe, Nigeria|Gombe]],<ref name=Omotosho>[http://unilorin.edu.ng/publications/omotoshoao/Religious%20Violence%20in%20Nigeria.pdf Religious Violence in Nigeria – the Causes and Solutions: an Islamic Perspective], A. O. Omotosho. Swedish Missiological Theme 2003, P. 15-31.</ref> where more Yan Tatsine riots occurred in April 1985. After the deaths of several hundred people Makaniki retreated to Cameroon, where he remained until 2004 when he was arrested in Nigeria.<ref name='pham'/>
The Islamist Quranist group [[Kala Kato]] are an off-shoot of the Yan Tatsine.
Some analysts view the terrorist group [[Boko Haram]] as an extension of the Maitatsine riots.<ref name='cfrBackgrounder'>{{cite web | url = http://www.cfr.org/africa/boko-haram/p25739 | title = Backgrounder: Boko Haram | accessdate = 2011-09-01 | last = Johnson | first = Toni | date = 31 August 2011 | publisher = Council on Foreign Relations}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Boko Haram]] *[[Religious violence in Nigeria]] *[[Islam in Nigeria]]
